paragraphs.text:
%md
# About This Lab
**Objective:** Work with datasets to analyze data and understand the difference between typed and untyped transformations
**Exercise Files:** 
    Exercise directory: /home/training/training_materials/devsh/exercises/datasets
    Data (local): /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/weblogs
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Working with Datasets in Scala

---

msg.data:
About This Lab

Objective: Work with datasets to analyze data and understand the difference between typed and untyped transformations
Exercise Files:

msg.data: Setup

paragraphs.title: Check HDFS for the weblogs directory
paragraphs.text:
%sh

# This is to ensure that the notebook runs from top to bottom without errors any number of time
hdfs dfs -rm -r -f -skipTrash /devsh_loudacre/accountIPs 

hdfs dfs -ls /devsh_loudacre/weblogs
# hdfs dfs -put -f /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/weblogs /devsh_loudacre/

%spark

val sc = spark.sparkContext

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab
---

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Explore Datasets Using Web Log Data

Find all the account IDs and the IP addresses from which those accounts logged in to the web site from Loudacre’s web log data.

msg.data:
Explore Datasets Using Web Log Data

Find all the account IDs and the IP addresses from which those accounts logged in to the web site from Loudacre’s web log data.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Create a AccountIP case class for account ID/IP address pairs
paragraphs.text: %spark

%md
Create an RDD of AccountIP objects by using the web log data in /devsh_loudacre/weblogs. Split the data by spaces and use the first field as IP address and 
the third as account ID.

```spark
val distinctIPDS = accountIPDS.distinct
val accountIPCountDS = distinctIPDS.groupBy("id","ip").count
```

paragraphs.title: 7 - Create a view on the AccountIPDS Dataset, and perform a SQL query on the view
paragraphs.text: %spark

%md
# Result
**You have now:** 

* created an RDD of account ID/IP address pairs, 
* created a new Dataset of products (case class objects) based on that RDD. 
* compared the results of typed and untyped transformations to better understand the relationship between DataFrames and Datasets.

---

msg.data:
Result

You have now:

  • created an RDD of account ID/IP address pairs,
  • created a new Dataset of products (case class objects) based on that RDD.
  • compared the results of typed and untyped transformations to better understand the relationship between DataFrames and Datasets.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Solution
---

msg.data: Solution

paragraphs.text:
%md
If you are not familiar with Scala then you should review class on Just Enough Scala
https://www.cloudera.com/about/training/courses/just-enough-scala.html

msg.data:
If you are not familiar with Scala then you should review class on Just Enough Scala
https://www.cloudera.com/about/training/courses/just-enough-scala.html

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Scala
Scala is a general-purpose programming language providing support for both object-oriented programming and functional programming. The parent language is 
Java. The language has a strong static type system. Like Java, Scala is object-oriented and uses a curly-brace syntax.

msg.data:
Scala

Scala is a general-purpose programming language providing support for both object-oriented programming and functional programming. The parent language is
Java. The language has a strong static type system. Like Java, Scala is object-oriented and uses a curly-brace syntax.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Datasets
The intent of Spark Datasets is to improve upon DataFrames and overcome the limitations of RDDs. A Spark Dataset is an extension on DataFrame API. The 
primary differences is Datasets are strongly typed and are mapped to a relational schema. Thus the structure of the data is always known. It represents 
structured queries with encoders. The encoder is primarily a serialization and deserialization (SerDes) framework in Spark SQL. The limitation for datasets 
is they are only available in Scala and Java.

msg.data:
Datasets

The intent of Spark Datasets is to improve upon DataFrames and overcome the limitations of RDDs. A Spark Dataset is an extension on DataFrame API. The
primary differences is Datasets are strongly typed and are mapped to a relational schema. Thus the structure of the data is always known. It represents
structured queries with encoders. The encoder is primarily a serialization and deserialization (SerDes) framework in Spark SQL. The limitation for datasets
is they are only available in Scala and Java.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Create an AccountIP case class for account ID/IP address pairs
paragraphs.text:
%spark

case class AccountIP (id: Int, ip: String)

msg.data: defined class AccountIP

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a schema AccountIP of field name and data type.

msg.data: Create a schema AccountIP of field name and data type.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a RDD of AccountIP objects from /devsh_loudacre/weblogs
paragraphs.text:
%spark

val accountIPRDD = sc.textFile("/devsh_loudacre/weblogs").map(line => line.split(' ')).map(fields => new AccountIP(fields(2).toInt,fields(0)))

msg.data: accountIPRDD: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[AccountIP] = MapPartitionsRDD[3] at map at <console>:27

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create an RDD of AccountIP objects by using the weblog data in /devsh_loudacre/weblogs.
Split the data by spaces and use the first field as IP address and the third as account ID.

msg.data:
Create an RDD of AccountIP objects by using the weblog data in /devsh_loudacre/weblogs.
Split the data by spaces and use the first field as IP address and the third as account ID.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create a Dataset of AccountIP objects using the new RDD
paragraphs.text:
%spark

val accountIPDS = spark.createDataset(accountIPRDD)

msg.data: accountIPDS: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[AccountIP] = [id: int, ip: string]

paragraphs.text:
%md
The Spark createDataset applies the AccountIP schema to the data collection.

msg.data: The Spark createDataset applies the AccountIP schema to the data collection.

paragraphs.title: 4 - View the schema and data in the new Dataset
paragraphs.text:
%spark

sc.setJobGroup("Using Datasets in Scala","View the schema and data in the new Dataset")
accountIPDS.show
accountIPDS.printSchema

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
The Spark Datasets extends the DataFrame API, so all DataFrame methods are now available.

msg.data: The Spark Datasets extends the DataFrame API, so all DataFrame methods are now available.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Compare the result types of typed and untyped transformations
paragraphs.text:
%spark

val distinctIPDS = accountIPDS.distinct
val accountIPCountDS = distinctIPDS.groupBy("id","ip").count

msg.data:
distinctIPDS: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[AccountIP] = [id: int, ip: string]
accountIPCountDS: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [id: int, ip: string ... 1 more field]

paragraphs.text:
%spark

distinctIPDS.printSchema
accountIPCountDS.printSchema

msg.data:
root
 |-- id: integer (nullable = false)
 |-- ip: string (nullable = true)

root
 |-- id: integer (nullable = false)
 |-- ip: string (nullable = true)
 |-- count: long (nullable = false)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Compare the result types of a typed transformation—distinct—and an untyped transformation—groupBy/count.

```spark
val distinctIPDS = accountIPDS.distinct
val accountIPCountDS = distinctIPDS.groupBy("id","ip").count
```

paragraphs.title: 6 - Save the accountIPDS Dataset as a Parquet file, then read the file back into a DataFrame
paragraphs.text:
%spark

sc.setJobGroup("Using Datasets in Scala","Save the accountIPDS Dataset as a Parquet file")
accountIPDS.write.save("/devsh_loudacre/accountIPs")

sc.setJobGroup("Using Datasets in Scala","Read the file back into a DataFrame")
val accountIPDF = spark.read.load("/devsh_loudacre/accountIPs")

msg.data: accountIPDF: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [id: int, ip: string]

paragraphs.text:
%spark

accountIPDS.printSchema
accountIPDF.printSchema

msg.data:
root
 |-- id: integer (nullable = false)
 |-- ip: string (nullable = true)

root
 |-- id: integer (nullable = true)
 |-- ip: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Save the accountIPDS Dataset as a Parquet file, then read the file back into a DataFrame.
Note that the type of the original Dataset (AccountIP) is not preserved, but the types of the columns are.

msg.data:

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Bonus Exercise

msg.data: Bonus Exercise

paragraphs.title: 7 - Create a view on the AccountIPDS Dataset, and perform a SQL query on the view
paragraphs.text:
%spark

sc.setJobGroup("Using Datasets in Scala","Create a view on the AccountIPDS Dataset, and perform a SQL query on the view")
accountIPDS.createOrReplaceTempView("account_ip")
val queryDF = spark.sql("SELECT DISTINCT *  FROM account_ip WHERE id < 200")
queryDF.printSchema

root
 |-- id: integer (nullable = false)
 |-- ip: string (nullable = true)

queryDF.show

paragraphs.title: Delete the Livy session
paragraphs.text:
%sh

sessionId=$(curl -s localhost:8998/sessions | jq '.sessions[0].id')
curl -s localhost:8998/sessions/$sessionId -X DELETE

msg.data: {"msg":"deleted"}

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Tutorials](http://cloudera.com/tutorials.html) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community](https://community.cloudera.com) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Apache Spark Documentation](https://spark.apache.org/documentation.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page](https://zeppelin.apache.org) - official Zeppelin web site.
